name: Bruce Hernandez
blurb:
Bruce is a founding partner of Spire Capital, having been with the firm since its inception in 2000. Bruce plays an active role in both sourcing and overseeing portfolio company investments and also works closely with the firm’s Chief Financial Officer in fund administration.

Prior to co-founding Spire, Bruce was the managing partner of Waller-Sutton Media Partners, a private equity firm focused primarily on the media and communications industries. Prior to Waller-Sutton, Bruce served in a number of operational roles. As Chief Financial Officer of Horizon Cellular, Bruce was responsible for all financial operations of this private equity backed wireless carrier and oversaw its sale for approximately $600 million. Bruce also served as Vice President-Finance of a middle market cable television and wireless telephone operator.

He received a Bachelor of Science degree in business administration from the University of Vermont and a Masters in business administration degree from New York University.

Bruce currently serves as Chairman of the Board of Surgent Professional Education and NetFortris. Bruce previously served as Chairman of the Board of Performance Assessment Network and Director of American Community Newspapers, Apex Site Management, Ariston Global, Certiport, Choice One Communications, Encoda Systems, Just Marketing International, Nassau Broadcasting Partners, Rainbow Child Care Centers, Sonitrol, and Orcom Solutions.

Bruce believes that “life is too short for bad gear” be it cars, bicycles or skis.

name: Marissa Paragano
blurb:
When people ask what my next job will be, I often tell them, “the role probably doesn’t exist yet.”

That’s what I've learned to love about the digital space. You zig. It zags.

My journey to digital started back in 2012 when I graduated GE's Financial Management Program; rather than following a century-long tradition of pursuing finance or accounting post-program, I went with my gut and took a sharp right turn into the then-infant digital space.

At the time, I was half of a two person team tasked with building out GE Capital Retail Finance’s mobile credit application sites, dubbed mApply.

By the time I left, 4 years had passed, GE Capital had IPO’ed its retail business to become Synchrony Financial, and we had collectively launched all but one (there’s always one…) of the company’s 20+ retail clients onto our mApply platform, providing millions of customers access to credit.

A few other cool things happened during that time:

I graduated NYU Stern with an MBA focused in Digital Marketing, and Entertainment, Media & Technology (and GE was cool enough to support my part-time pursuit of it);
GE Capital Retail Finance launched its first Innovation Station, and its leadership team selected 17 lucky colleagues and me to drive innovation throughout the company as inaugural members;
Synchrony gave me the go ahead to run not just the mobile credit platform (mApply), but also the desktop credit platform (eApply), effectively tripling my purview;
I convinced leadership that we should destroy the e and mApply sites we’d spent years building, in favor of a single adaptive responsive digital apply (dApply) site;
I also ran my first half marathon, and invested in my first multi-family property

After Synchrony, I spent a year in SF leading product/digital marketing for a segment of CoreLogic, then headed back east to develop digital products for Goldman Sachs’s awesome new-ish consumer segment, Marcus. Today I help drive digital innovation at JPMorgan Chase.
